title: With Jack Ma’s Retirement, Alibaba Loses Its Brash, Charismatic Leader
text:
HANGZHOU, China—There is no one in Chinese business like Jack Ma, and it may be a long time before anyone like him comes around again.

On Tuesday, his 55th birthday, China’s richest person plans to step down as executive chairman of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. BABA 0.62% , the nearly half-trillion-dollar online-shopping giant that he co-founded in an apartment in this southern Chinese city two decades ago. For his third act, the former English teacher plans to return to education, where he wants to focus his philanthropic energies.

Mr. Ma’s departure will leave an absence atop China’s corporate world, where for years he cut a charismatic figure as the most recognizable business leader. Mr. Ma won fame inside and outside the country for his brash proclamations; at the company’s annual mass wedding ceremony for employees this year, he encouraged couples not only to work 72 hours a week, but also to spend their free time procreating.

By contrast, his peers among the Chinese tech giants—and his successor as Alibaba executive chairman, current Chief Executive Daniel Zhang —are far less flamboyant. “He’s the face of Chinese business overseas and domestically, too,” said Duncan Clark, the Beijing-based author of “Alibaba: The House that Jack Ma Built” and an early investor in the company. “Now he’s aspiring to be the face of philanthropy, environmentalism and education, and with that the subtext of how tech can be a force for good.” As the Chinese government under President Xi Jinping shifts to promoting state-owned enterprises while tightening oversight of privately run ones, it is making business leaders nervous about becoming too visible, Mr. Clark said. “The conditions are not ripe now for another individual icon to emerge.” Mr. Ma has slowly transitioned out of Alibaba leadership. He resigned as chief executive in 2013 and gave notice a year ago that he would depart as chairman. Unlike Bill Gates, who dove into charity work after leaving Microsoft Corp. , Mr. Ma will keep a hand in tech. He plans to remain on an Alibaba governing board and is, in his personal capacity, the controlling shareholder of Ant Financial, a sister company of Alibaba that provides digital-payment services. Mr. Ma for years has spoken about and pledged money to causes focused on environmental conservation, wildlife preservation and climate change, going so far as to criticize the state of pollution in China. More recently, he spoke at a women’s conference about increasing female participation in developing technology. In a letter to shareholders and employees last year, Mr. Ma said no one person could be chairman or chief executive forever “because of the physical limits on one’s ability and energy.” But he added that he “still had a lot of dreams to pursue” and wanted “to return to education, which excites me with so much blessing because this is what I love to do.” Alibaba employees expect their leader to go out on an extravagant note. To celebrate Mr. Ma’s birthday and retirement on Tuesday, tens of thousands of employees will flock to a stadium in Hangzhou to mark the company’s 20th anniversary. Previous anniversary parties have featured celebrity cameos and even a performance by Mr. Ma himself, who appeared on stage dressed and dancing like Michael Jackson.
